;;一名戴头巾的妇女
;

;伊朗当局逮捕了一名著名律师和人权捍卫者，称其为她的丈夫说，她参加了一名少女的葬礼，这名少女在一场有争议的地铁事故中死亡。

;

;纳斯林·索托德 (Nasrin Sotoudeh) 周日在德黑兰 16 岁阿米塔·加拉万德 (Armita Garawand) 的葬礼上被捕，;谁死了一天前;，经过近一个月的重症监护。

;

;索托德，60 岁，因其人权工作而被授予欧洲议会 2012 年萨哈罗夫奖，;近年来多次被捕;。

;

;“我的妻子在阿米塔·加拉旺德的葬礼上与其他人一起被捕，”索托德的丈夫礼萨·坎丹 (Reza Khandan) 告诉法新社，并称她在被捕期间“遭到暴力殴打”。

;

;青少年 ;10 月 1 日，她在地铁上发生了一起事故，导致她陷入昏迷，被送往德黑兰的晨曦医院;，对于她的受伤方式，人们的看法存在巨大分歧。

;

;她在 10 月 1 日去世。一年后;马赫萨·阿米尼 (Mahsa Amini) 在拘留期间死亡;，也是一名年轻的伊朗库尔德人，他因涉嫌在一次引发大规模抗议的事件中违反伊朗严格的妇女着装规范而被道德警察逮捕。

;

;当地法尔斯通讯社称，索托德因“未戴头巾”和“扰乱社会精神安全”而“已被逮捕并移交给司法当局”。

;

;在公共场合遮盖颈部和头部已成为自 1979 年伊朗伊斯兰革命之后，自 1983 年起，女性就开始强制要求着装。

;

;自去年 9 月阿米尼在押期间死亡后爆发长达数月的示威以来，女性越来越无视伊斯兰共和国严格的着装规定。阿米尼因涉嫌违反着装规定而被捕。

;

;索托德本人 ;此前曾于 2018 年入狱;，原因是为一名因伊朗示威反对强制戴头巾而被捕的妇女辩护。

;

;然后在 2019 年， ;她被判处因被指控“鼓励腐败和放荡”而入狱 12 年。

;

;加拉万德的案件于 10 月 3 日由库尔德人权组织 Hengaw 首次报道，该组织称她在德黑兰地铁发生的涉及伊朗道德警察的事件。

;

;但当局表示，她的血压突然下降，并否认发生过任何“身体或言语争执”。

;

;国家电视台播出的地铁监控录像显示，这名未戴口罩的少年在车厢内晕倒后被疏散。

;;街道上的待售标志广告
;

;最近的利率上涨被归咎于因自 Covid-19 大流行以来结束了英国的财富繁荣并导致家庭总财富暴跌了四分之一。

;

;智库决议基金会和资产管理公司 Abrdn 的一份报告称，这一下降是由于房价和养老金的下降，这两项收入约占财富总额的每 5 英镑中的 4 英镑，并在疫情爆发前的 40 年里对全国财富的增长发挥了主导作用。

;

;然而，自英国央行于 2021 年 12 月开始加息以来，两者的价值均有所下降。虽然 2021 年家庭总财富占国内生产总值 (GDP) 的 840%，但已跌至 GDP 的 630%分辨率基金会 (Resolution Foundation) 研究员伊恩·穆尔海恩 (Ian Mulheirn) 表示，“利率上升结束了英国的财富繁荣，并导致自疫情以来家庭总财富直线下降。”

;

;较高的利率增加了抵押贷款的成本，导致借款人的需求减弱，进而迫使卖家降低房价。

;

;养老基金是政府债券的大量持有者，而政府债券的价格已经下跌由于通胀预期上升，投资者要求更高的回报率。

;

;英格兰银行将宣布其下一个;周四利率决定;。虽然政策制定者最有可能将基准利率维持在 5.25%，但长期较高利率的前景表明英国家庭财富可能会继续减少。

;

;决议基金会解释说，影响可能是不均匀，并且会因年龄和地区而异。例如，总财富的下降对于年轻人来说往往是个好消息，他们能够以更便宜的价格购买房屋，并且今天购买的债券将获得比几年前更好的回报率。

;

;但房价下跌对于那些已经在苏格兰、威尔士和英格兰北部等较便宜地区拥有房屋的人来说可能是个坏消息，因为这可能会更快地使一些家庭面临陷入负资产的风险——其中该房产的价值低于抵押贷款的剩余价值。

;

;Mulheirn 表示，地区差异已经很明显。 “今年房价下跌的影响并没有均匀地分布在全国各地，苏格兰、威尔士和英格兰北部等不太富裕的地区财富下降幅度最大，而英格兰南部和东部等房价高的地区则出现了最大的财富下降。”

;

;“虽然未来情况可能会发生变化，但这些地区差异再次凸显了需要进行一系列改革，以使家庭免受财富波动的影响，财富波动会根据运气在代际之间转移资源。更公平、更有效的财富税是该议程的关键部分，英国最大的财富税——议会税——尤其需要进行改革，使其更有针对性、更少累退”，他补充道。

;;巨树穿过霍巴特市中心
;

;一棵百年树的照片一辆驶过霍巴特市中心的卡车后面出现了新的声音，引发了新的呼吁，要求修改法律，以保护塔斯马尼亚的原生森林免遭砍伐。

;

;该市主要街道麦格理街 (Macquarie Street) 上的伐木卡车的图像环境组织鲍勃·布朗基金会在网上发布了南北大道的信息。这是近几个月来;在该州道路上拖运;的一系列大树照片中的最新一张。

;

;抗议者阻止了霍巴特南部克曼迪附近地区的伐木活动，科学家称该地区有大树，可以用来筑巢 ;极度濒危的雨燕鹦鹉;，一种在塔斯马尼亚繁殖的迁徙物种。

;
;

;;相关：;;“国家耻辱”：塔斯马尼亚砍伐估计有数百年历史的树木后举行抗议;

;
;

;周五，他们将自己锁在进入伐木区的大门上，周一，临时强制阻止现场工作。周一有一人被捕。

;

;鲍勃·布朗基金会的竞选经理珍妮·韦伯 (Jenny Weber) 表示，根据州和国家法律，砍伐卡车上照片中的那棵树是合法的，据信这是;;桉树;;，估计胸高直径接近 3 米，树龄至少 200 年。

; ;

;环保主义者呼吁塔斯马尼亚政府遵循;西澳大利亚;和;维多利亚;宣布结束原生森林采伐和联邦政府加强对受威胁物种栖息地的保护，作为;承诺彻底修改国家保护法;。

;

;“塔斯马尼亚伐木的问题在于它完全受到国家批准和联邦政府，”韦伯说。 “我们没有像维多利亚州那样制定能够终止原生森林采伐的法律。”

;

;塔斯马尼亚自由党政府和工党反对派都支持持续进行的原生森林采伐。总理杰里米·罗克利夫承认，在受保护的森林和“公共生产森林”中都存在具有“国家和国际意义”的巨树，并认为该州拥有完善的程序来保护后者。

; <旁白>;

;;相关：;;'实时观察灭绝：如果继续砍伐，自然资源保护主义者对澳大利亚的雨燕鹦鹉失去希望#birdoftheyear;

; ;

;政府已邀请受即将到来的原生森林砍伐禁令影响的维多利亚州公司参与其中州申请运输合同。照片中在麦格理街运载这棵树的卡车挂有维多利亚时代的车牌。

;

;该国有机构以前称为塔斯马尼亚林业局，现称为塔斯马尼亚可持续木材局 (STT)，;将巨型树木定义为至少 85 米高;或估计茎体积至少 280 立方米。这些树木的直径通常约为 5 米，需要 100 米的缓冲区进行保护。

;

;森林生态学家、保护组织 Tree Projects 的联合创始人 Jen Sanger 描述道这个定义是“完全任意的”。

;

;抗议者瞄准了 STT 命名为 KD022C 的伐木区。在本月早些时候的 Instagram 帖子中，该机构表示已在该地点开始“小型 20 公顷森林采伐作业”。它;发布了该区域的图片;，并将其描述为再生原生森林轿跑车。

; ;

;STT 在帖子中表示，在对该地区进行调查时，它发现了燕尾鹦鹉在头顶飞过，但没有发现觅食或筑巢活动。它说三棵潜在筑巢树将被排除在砍伐范围之外。

;

;在周一下午的一份声明中，STT 保护和土地管理总经理 Suzette Weeding 确认卡车上照片中的树来自轿跑车 KD022C。她说它是在从森林运输到塔斯马尼亚客户时拍摄的，并将用于“高质量外观级产品，如塔斯马尼亚橡木地板或住房”。

;

;她说，该机构已管理森林“实现多种价值，包括木材生产和保护”是一项重要责任。

;

;保护生物学家马特·韦伯 (Matt Webb) 表示，他两周前在轿跑车中看到了迅捷鹦鹉，当时还处于早期阶段。繁殖季节，并且该地区仅保留三棵树是不够的。 “它位于迅猛鹦鹉重要繁殖区的中间，之前曾有人提议在那里建造轿跑车，但都被否决了。我真的希望在很大程度上停止对该地区雨燕鹦鹉栖息地的砍伐，”他说。

;

;科学家称雨燕鹦鹉 ;可能在十年内灭绝;，而伐木是它面临的最大威胁。

;

;澳大利亚近 90% 的木材来自种植园，只有 12% 来自原生森林。 ;最近的劳工环境行动网络的报告;称，自2010年以来，种植林场的数量很少，而且种植总面积正在下降。它呼吁建立一个国有的国家种植园，以结束原生森林采伐。

;;黑斯廷斯老城
;

;英格兰的住房危机将迫使许多地方当局破产，因为成本不断增加领导人警告说，为数千个无家可归家庭提供的紧急住宿可能会超出议会预算。

;

;受灾最严重的议会现在每年花费数百万英镑 - 在某些情况下占其总额的五分之一到一半可用的财政资源 - 试图应对由于租金上涨和经济适用房供应减少而导致的无家可归者空前迅速的激增。

;

;危机的规模意味着规模较小的议会，通常是在富裕的郡县，正在努力提供足够的紧急住房来履行支持无家可归家庭的法律义务。一些地区的无家可归率同比增加了一倍以上。

;
;

;;相关：;;英格兰“破碎”的住房系统现在是一个议会无法避免的问题;;

;

;多年来一直享有住房稳定的议会现在却因危机的成本不断上升而感到震惊。埃塞克斯郡巴西尔登区议会的临时住宿支出从 2017 年的 7,000 英镑增加到 2022 年的 200 万英镑。东萨塞克斯郡的黑斯廷斯区议会在 2019 年花费了 75 万英镑，但预计到明年 4 月，其年度账单将达到 560 万英镑。

;

;地方政府就需要采取紧急部长行动达成了跨党派共识，甚至保守党控制的议会也呼吁实行租金管制、提高住房福利率以及投资新的社会住房，以防止危机避免将较小的地区拖入破产。

;

;“除非政府现在采取行动，否则我们中的许多人将在财务上陷入困境，对当地服务造成毁灭性影响。区议会网络住房发言人汉娜·道尔顿 (Hannah Dalton) 表示，区议会提供的安全网的衰落将对我们社区中最脆弱的成员造成最严重的打击。

;

;《卫报》对地方当局收入支出的分析发现 10 个议会在 2022-23 年间，每 10 英镑的核心支出（不受限制且议会可以用来做出决策）中有超过 1 英镑用于临时住宿。

; ;

;许多议会的临时住所人数也大幅增加。在西萨塞克斯郡的克劳利，2019 年 12 月至今年 3 月期间，家庭数量翻了一番；根据政府的无家可归者数据，黑斯廷斯的无家可归者人数增加了两倍，汉普郡的哈文特则增加了十倍。由于抵押贷款利率上升，迫使房东出售房屋或转向短期租赁（例如 Airbnb），住房福利削减以及合适住房的稀缺，迫使潜在的首次购房者留在出租房中。

;

;地方议会描述了随着危机蔓延，当地私人租赁住房市场状况日益混乱，包括：

;
    ;
  • ;

    ;无良私人房东驱逐租户，然后将房产提供给地方议会用作临时住所并收取更高的租金——这个过程被称为“翻转”。

    ;
    • ;
;
    ;
  • ;

    ;越来越多的家庭被安置在距离他们居住地几英里远的临时住房中。来自他们孩子的学校。埃塞克斯郡的区议会通常为诺福克郡和剑桥郡的家庭提供住所，据报道，其中一个家庭被安置在苏格兰北部的因弗内斯。

    ;
    • ;
;
    ;
  • ;

    ;议会直接负责与内政部及其寻求庇护者住房承包商 Serco 和 Clearsprings 竞争，以确保其所在地区稀缺的临时住宿。一些市政府正在考虑向房东提供“黄金问候”现金支付，以确保优先入住房屋。

    ;
    • ;
;
;

;;相关：;;《卫报》对无家可归者人数上升的看法：政府制造的危机|社论;

;
;

;;上周公布的英格兰最新数据;显示，临时住所的家庭数量达到创纪录的 104,000 户，纳税人损失了 17 亿英镑。市议会表示，由于越来越多的工薪家庭在被希望出售或提高租金的房东赶走后无家可归，导致这一数字不断上升。

;

;切姆斯福德市议会自由民主党领袖斯蒂芬·罗宾逊 (Stephen Robinson) 表示： “作为一个国家，我们已经 30 年没有建造足够的房屋了。如果无家可归的危机得不到解决，两年内许多地区议会和单一议会可能会破产，其中英格兰东南部的议会面临的风险尤其大。”工党黑斯廷斯曾表示，最近的一篇论文称，由于临时住宿费用上涨，实际上;面临破产;金融和社会后果是如此严重，以至于“即使是‘住房危机’这个词也不足以表达我们面临的系统性和内在的挑战”。

;

;政府发言人表示，部长们致力于确保家庭能够从临时住所搬进稳定的住房。 “地方当局发现 2022-23 年核心支出能力将增加高达 51 亿英镑，即以现金计算增长 9.4%，英格兰地方政府可使用近 600 亿英镑。

;

;“我们致力于首先，通过在无家可归现象发生之前预防其发生来减少对临时住宿的需求，这就是为什么我们在三年内通过无家可归预防补助金向议会提供 10 亿英镑。”

;

;经过四个月的听证会，官方 Covid 调查达到了一周的巨大规模重要且可能具有毁灭性的证词，这些证据可能会给鲍里斯·约翰逊政府的内部运作带来深刻的无情的启示。

;

;证人包括约翰逊的前首席顾问多米尼克·卡明斯 (Dominic Cummings) 和他的前通信者李·凯恩 (Lee Cain) chief, plus a string of other senior aides and top civil servants of the time – several of whom first became known to the public because of illicit Covid parties.

;

;These include Martin Reynolds, who was dubbed “Party Marty ” after ;an email emerged; showing he had invited more than 100 Downing Street staff to a “bring your own booze” event during the first lockdown.

;

;Another is Helen MacNamara, the Johnson government's head of ethics, ;who apologised ; for being fined over a lockdown-breaking staff leaving party in June 2020, for which she was said to have provided a karaoke machine.

;

;One scheduled box-office witness, cabinet secretary Simon Case, the head of the civil service under Johnson and still in post, has been put back until later this year because of a medical procedure.

;
;

;;Related: ;;UK lockdowns were a policy ' failure', health expert tells Covid inquiry;

;
;

;The four days of hearings, which include testimony from other close Johnson aides as well as NHS and health department chiefs, could also prove damaging for Rishi Sunak, who was chancellor at the time and intimately involved in the decisions.

;

;There are two main political perils for Sunak: that he gets further drawn into what has already been troubling evidence about the pace at which Johnson's government first responded to Covid; and that new revelations about parties revive public memories of the scandal.

;

;The parallel ;second module of the inquiry;, which looks at political governance and decision-making, has already shown a tendency to jump around in terms of chronology and narrative, unexpectedly providing revelations as messages and emails are displayed.

;

;One such twist came in the last evidence session, on 19 October, when a string of September 2020 WhatsApp messages between Dame Angela McLean, now the government's chief scientific adviser, and leading epidemiologist John Edmunds showed ;McLean referring to Sunak; as “Dr Death the chancellor” because of the impact of his “eat out to help out” scheme.

;

;This uncertainty will become all the greater because of the characters of some of those involved, not least Cummings, who has shown complete willingness to trash the reputation of Johnson, whom he calls “the shopping trolley” for his supposed abrupt ;veering between decisions;.

;

;Last week, George Osborne, the former chancellor, ;said he had been told; that some of the WhatsApp messages between Johnson and Cummings handed to the inquiry included “really pretty disgusting language and misogynistic language”.

;

;While less known to the public than Cummings, Cain was also a hugely important figure inside No 10. A longtime aide to Johnson, the former journalist was his director of communications before he was ;pushed out alongside Cummings; in November 2020.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Cabinet turmoil a key reason for 'dismal' UK response to Covid, inquiry told;

;
;

;Cain has already shown he could directly challenge Sunak's narrative. Last year, when Sunak claimed he had tried to discuss the potential downsides of lockdowns in cabinet but was quashed by scientists, Cain called this “Covid revisionism”.

;

;Rather than rushing into lockdowns, Cain is expected to argue, the Johnson government's main mistake had been to delay them too long, a worry raised in recent hearings by eminent scientists including Edmunds ;and Neil Ferguson;.

;

;Amid the inevitable political drama, gossip and score-settling, it is important to remember that all this will be closely watched by the families of those who died, who are among the designated “core participants”.

;

;Later this year it will be the politicians' turn to explain themselves to the inquiry. If by then a narrative has already been established that dithering or infights meant the death toll was higher than necessary, this could prove a deeply uncomfortable experience.

;

;Antisemitism is a “deeply ingrained racism in European society” that poses an existential threat to the continent's Jewish community and the fundamental aims of the European Union, an EU official has warned.

;

;Michael O'Flaherty, the director of the bloc's agency for fundamental rights, said it was worrying that only a third of the general population considered antisemitism a big problem, when there was no doubt “dramatic moments in our societies trigger antisemitic responses”.

;

;He told the Guardian: “It happened with Covid, it's happening now with the Russian aggression [in Ukraine] – and now it's happening again. Media and civil society organisations warn of a rise of antisemitism as the crisis in the Middle East unfolds.

;

;“I honestly think that with any big negative issue in our society, you're going to find antisemitic tropes finding their way in there. It's indicative of the extent … antisemitism is a deeply ingrained racism in European society.”

;

;O'Flaherty added that it was “also important at this time to be vigilant and condemn all forms of hatred that manifest themselves in Europe, including hatred against Muslims”.

;

;The war that has followed the terrorist attacks by Hamas in Israel on 7 October has led to an unprecedented increase in antisemitic incidents. High numbers of civilian casualties caused by Israel's response have raised tensions further.

;

;Recent figures compiled by the US-based Anti-Defamation League (ADL) revealed a 300% rise in Austria. In the UK, London police said 218 antisemitic hate crimes had been reported from 1-18 October,more than 13 times more than the same period last year.

;

;In Germany, the antisemitism monitoring organisation RIAS reported a 240% increase in ;antisemitic incidents; since 7 October, a total the country's antisemitism commissioner warned ;risked transporting the country back to its “most horrific times”.;

;

;Many ;experts in hate crimes; point to deeply rooted negative ideas about Jews that, though always present, surface at times of societal stress.

; ;

;;One recent study; by the ADL found that anti-Jewish tropes remained entrenched in 10 European countries, with roughly one in four people harbouring historically familiar antisemitic beliefs, particularly false beliefs about Jews and money, and Jews controlling governments.

;

;Polling carried out among Europe's Jewish communities found that 90% of respondents felt antisemitism was getting worse, said O'Flaherty. “So that is the strong view of the Jewish community itself. What's more, they predominantly said … that the single biggest problem in their lives is antisemitism. That is quite startling. It was not about a job, healthcare, education, putting food on the table … It was antisemitism.”

;

;Experts estimate the “core” Jewish population of the EU to be 781,200, though many more have at least one parent who identifies as Jewish. The population immediately after the second world war and the Holocaust, ;which killed at least 6 million European Jews;, was about 3.8 million.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Bavaria leader declines to dismiss deputy over antisemitic leaflet;

;
;

;Now that very few survivors were still alive, Europe must find a new way of communicating the tragedy of the Holocaust, O'Flaherty said, calling for greater efforts in education.

;

;“Another aspect that is very relevant right now … is the extent to which we are forgetting about the Holocaust,” he said. “Almost all the survivors have gone now … and we are yet to find a new way of effectively transmitting the story to our children, to people in our societies.”

;

;The ADL found that, among the six countries polled in western Europe, Spain remained the country with the highest level of antisemitic attitudes, with 26% of the population harbouring extensive antisemitic beliefs, followed by Belgium (24%), France (17%), Germany (12%) and the UK (10%). In the Netherlands, only 6% of those polled held antisemitic views.

;

;In eastern Europe, antisemitic attitudes were more widely held, though becoming rarer. The ADL found high levels of antisemitic beliefs in Hungary (37%) and Poland (35%).

;

;Studies have confirmed a ;sharp rise in online antisemitism; in Europe during the Covid pandemic and after the Russian invasion of Ukraine last year.

; ;

;AFR research has revealed a ;growing number of Jews; who say they would consider leaving Europe as a consequence of prejudice and discrimination.

;

;“It is an existential issue in the sense that when we asked Jews whether they would consider leaving Europe, a significant number said they would … And more worrying still, when you look at who are those Jews, they are mainly young,” said O' Flaherty, previously a professor of human rights law at the National University of Ireland.

;

;“We built the modern Europe on the basis of the repudiation of the horrors of the second world war, and uppermost of those horrors is and was the Holocaust – the genocide perpetrated against Jews … That's why the persistent assault on this relatively small community of people is of such fundamental importance for Europe and for the values that we claim to uphold.”

;

;Experts say the issue of emigration and the decline of Jewish populations in much of Europe is complicated. In some countries, including the UK and Austria, Jewish communities are growing, albeit incrementally as immigration offsets deaths among an often elderly population. In others, such as Germany, Jewish population levels are stable. However, many small communities never recovered from the Holocaust, and a further decline in numbers of Jewish communities in Europe appears inevitable.

;

;Most emigration by European Jews is driven by the same factors that prompt the movement of members of any other community: a search for stability, security and prosperity, research by the ;Institute for Jewish Policy Research; (JPR) has shown.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Roald Dahl museum acknowledges author's antisemitism;

;
;

;Violent attacks that target Jews or are motivated by ideologies that have strong antisemitic elements can be linked to increases in emigration by Jews, such as from France between 2015 and 2016 when the country was rocked by a series of terrorist attacks, including several against Jewish targets.

;

;Jonathan Boyd, the executive director of the JPR in London, told the Guardian in September: “Many European countries where there were once really big vibrant Jewish communities now have tiny Jewish populations – often just a few thousand – which are ageing and really struggling to maintain themselves … When you have antisemitism on top of that, it obviously doesn't help.

;

;“When people are very worried by that – particularly when it becomes murderous – the fears become acute enough to push some at least to leave.”

;Regional media has emerged as a new front in the contest between the US and China in the Pacific, as Washington said it will support “free media” while warning of the dangers of Beijing's efforts to manipulate information around the world.

;

;During a visit to countries in the Indo-Pacific in October, the US under secretary for public diplomacy and public affairs, Elizabeth Allen, said Washington was “prioritising the support of independent media” across the region.

;

;Speaking to the Guardian in Sydney, Allen said the support would take “different forms'' and the US would look to partner with media sectors in the Pacific.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Solomon Islands prime minister says US must respect Pacific leaders ;

;
;

;“As part of advocating for a free and open Indo-Pacific, we are going to advocate for free media across the region,” she said, adding independent media is “critical to any democracy”.

;

;“We're certainly looking to partner with media sectors across the region, and giving them more support,” Allen said.

;

;Her comments come amid a wider battle for influence between Washington and Beijing in the Pacific. The US has been criticised for being largely absent as a partner in the Pacific for decades, but in recent years it has significantly stepped up its presence, scrambling to ;open embassies; and conducting ;high-level visits; in the region.

;

;The US already provides access to wire services such as Associated Press to newsrooms in several Pacific countries. Allen said the US would continue to look for opportunities to encourage independent journalism, which may include “how to create access outlets like AP, AFP wire services … to make sure that they're getting access to objective editorially sound information.”

;

;Allen's visit follows rising anxiety about China's ambitions in the Pacific. In 2022, Beijing rattled Western countries by securing a ;security pact with Solomon Islands.; In May, the US struck a ;defence cooperation deal with Papua New Guinea;, a country just north of Australia seen as strategically significant.

;

;US president Joe Biden hosted Pacific leaders at a summit in Washington in September, pledging more aid to the region. Solomon Islands prime minister Manasseh Sogavare, now closely aligned with China, skipped the talks and said the US must change its strategy when it came to meeting Pacific leaders and ;stop “lecturing” them.; China's president Xi Jinping has argued his country's outreach to Pacific countries is based on respect for those nations' ;“sovereignty and independence”.;

;

;Shailendra Singh, head of journalism at the University of the South Pacific, said the media was “central to the big power contest in the region.”

;

;“All the countries jostling for influence are wooing the media, one way or another to win Pacific citizens' hearts and minds because this can influence government decisions, at least to some extent,” Singh said.

;

;Earlier this year several newspapers in Solomon Islands were accused of ;compromising their independence ;in return for resources from China.

;

;“China is certainly very active,” Singh said, while Canberra and Washington have been “a bit slower coming to the party.”

;

;During Allen's visit, which included stops in Fiji and Vanuatu, the under secretary launched the Pacific hub for the ;Digital Communications Network; (DCN). The DCN, an NGO supported by the US state department, is described as a collaborative platform to “address challenges to democracy and the information space.”

;

;“We are focused on free media and the information space as evidenced by the Digital Communications Network,” Allen said.

;

;She said misinformation and disinformation was a “global problem.”

;

;“There's no country that's immune to it, including the United States.”

;

;While not naming specific countries that had sought to manipulate information or influence media in the Pacific region, Allen noted a recent report published by the US state department on how ;China is influencing the information ;environment around the world.

;

;The ;report; outlined tactics used by Beijing to manipulate information. It states that China “employs a variety of deceptive and coercive methods as it attempts to influence the international information environment” including propaganda, disinformation, and censorship.

;

;Singh said the small media systems of the Pacific face many challenges, which include lagging in emerging technologies, as well as being vulnerable to disinformation and manipulation.

;

;“The US certainly has a role supporting free media in the Pacific to counter illiberalism and shore up democracy,” he said.

;Trump had been granted a reprieve when the judge temporarily lifted the gag order while she considered that request. Prosecutors argued last week that the order should be reimposed after Trump took advantage and posted a slew of inflammatory statements.

;“The defendant has capitalized on the court's administrative stay to, among other prejudicial conduct, send an unmistakable and threatening message to a foreseeable witness in this case,” prosecutors said in their brief. “Unless the court lifts the administrative stay, the defendant will not stop.”

;Prosecutors also suggested that after Trump was fined $10,000 for flouting a similar gag order imposed in the civil fraud case brought by the New York state attorney general Laeticia James, Trump should also face consequences for assailing parties in the criminal case in Washington.
